Award.AwardTitle: A Quantum Embedding Approach to Understanding Biological N2 Fixation
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Thomas Miller from the California Institute of Technology to investigate nitrogen fixation in biological and synthetic chemical systems. Understanding nitrogen fixation (breaking N2 into more useful forms) is a challenge of paramount scientific, industrial and societal importance. The predominant route for nitrogen fixation is the Haber-Bosch process, resulting in ammonia (NH3). Beyond this process few advances have been made to fix nitrogen, especially at mild temperatures and pressures. The search for other routes that operate under various conditions and understanding how they work are among the most elusive challenges in the chemical sciences. Recently developed computational quantum chemistry methods are employed in this research to achieve a detailed characterization of pathways involved in nitrogen fixation. Throughout this pursuit graduate students and postdoctoral fellows are acquiring specialized training in electronic structure theory and reaction dynamics of complex systems. New theoretical methods to advance the accuracy and efficiency of what is computationally obtainable, are being employed and developed in this research. This project is integrated into an outreach program to introduce high school students and high school science teachers to the science of computational chemistry.

This research project is undertaken to characterize important catalytic pathways and reaction intermediates for the fixation of nitrogen via biological and synthetic catalysts. The research approach applies recently developed quantum embedding methods that enable high-level descriptions of the electronic wave-functions (such as CCSD(T) or CASPT2) in the reaction center of transition metal catalysts at dramatically reduced computational costs. The project involves the use of these powerful new theoretical methods to elucidate the catalytic pathways for nitrogen reduction in both single-site and two-site synthetic models of the FeMo-cofactor. In addition the project incorporates full-scale studies of the nitrogenase FeMo-cofactor with protein and solvent environment. The project addresses physical questions and methodological challenges that are at the forefront of biological, inorganic, and theoretical chemistry research. The project will yield critical insights into the catalytic pathways for nitrogen reduction, clear mechanistic insights into both model complexes that are testable in the synthetic laboratory, as well as characterizations and predictions for the nitrogenase enzyme in its full complexity. Furthermore, the project is synergistic with NSF research priorities related to catalytic activation of other small molecules (such as H2 and CO2), as well as with the Innovations at the Nexus of Food, Energy and Water Systems (INFEWS) initiative.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In biology, nitrogen fixation is performed by nitrogenase enzymes. The predominant synthetic pathway for nitrogen fixation is the Haber-Bosch process, beyond which few advances have been made in the selective activation of molecular nitrogen, especially at mild temperatures and pressures. The search for nitrogen activation catalysts that operate under ambient conditions and the effort to understand how biology achieves this remarkable success are among the most elusive and important challenges in the chemical sciences. Quantum chemistry methods have the potential to make extraordinary contributions in this area by allowing for the detailed characterization of catalytic pathways and reaction intermediates. However, major theoretical obstacles currently hinder the reliable and efficient computational modeling of N2 fixation and other small-molecule activation processes. In particular, widely used theoretical methods, such as density functional theory (DFT), introduce a compromise between accuracy and efficiency that can be inadequate for the predictive modeling of catalytic pathways. To address this problem, we have recently developed quantum embedding methods that mitigate this trade-off between accuracy and efficiency by allowing for high-level descriptions of the electronic wavefunction (such as CCSD(T) or CASPT2) in the reaction center of transition metal catalysts. Working in close collaboration with experimentalists at Caltech and elsewhere, this research has led to new theoretical methods to elucidate the catalytic pathways for small-molecular activation.  The outcome of this work includes eight published articles, four of which were highlighted by leading journals as Editor's Choice.
